document.text: Wanted  Twenty shares of stock of Farmers National Bank, Appomattox, Va. W. B. C a ld w ell . Mr. and Mrs. H G. Smith and children, of North Carolina,are visiting friends and relatives here this week. Miss Edna Turnes, of Darling ton Heights, is spending her vacation with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. W. L. Turnes, at Turnes Mill. Misses Earle Patteson and Virginia Puckette have return ed home after a visit to their cousin, Miss Anna Jordan, in Charlotte. Appomattox- High School having closed for this session, Miss Edmonia Hardy, one of the teachers, has gone to Madison Heights. Mrs. Carrie Cunningham, of Amherst, has been on a visit to the home of Mr. J. R. Caldwell for some days. She left for home Friday. Private Larkin Williams is back from France looking fine. Larkin is a good farmer and will make his share of the crops of Appomattox. Letters to friends here from Privates Marion Ponton and Bernard Turnes announce their arrival in New York from over seas. Our Supervisors are in see -sion today. No road work of importance going on in the county, our fathers will have little to do except pay the sala ry account of county officers.

Webb and his men decided to enter retreads the following year, and again in 1975 and 1976. Webbs Tire Company was awarded blue ribbons by the American Retreaders Association few the top quality retreads it produced. Webbs son, Doug, began to help his father in the family business during sum mers and on weekends while in high school. A fter receiving his degree in Political Science from Hamp den Sydney College to 1977, Doug went to work for the Farmers National Bank of Appomattox. When Martin Webb decided to retire in 1982, Doug left his position at the bank in order to take over management of the family business. Today the Webb Tire Company team consists qf Doug Webb, Manager Todd Craft, Assistant Manager Charles Booker and James Pannell, Retreaders Ches- ley Christian, John Torrence and Marco Turner, Tire Technicians and S h e lia Webb, Bookkepper. document.text: Over 100 Appomattox County 4- H members will be partici pating in a county-wide public speaking program within the coming week. 4-Hers in grades 5- 12 are eligible to enter the program. 4-H members will be speak ing on topics of their own choice in qualifying contests to be held at each school this week. Win ners in the contests to be held at A ppo ma tt ox Intermediate School on Tuesday and Wednes day and at Pamplin Elementary on Friday will compete in a County Public Speaking Contest on Wednesday, March 1, at A.I. S. Time for the county contest will be 730 p.m. Teenage 4-Hers will also be competing on March 1 for the right to represent Appomattox County in a District Speaking program in April. One boy and one girl will be chosen to re present the county. Farmers National Bank of Appomattox is sponsoring the awards for the speaking pro gram. Each participant will re ceive a blue, red, or white rib bon plus a 4-H Certificate of Recognition. Also, boy and girl winners in the county contest, I .grades 5 - 8 , will receive trophies. document.text: Miss Ann W. Fletcher, age 17, daughter of Mr. Neal E. Fletcher, Jr. and Mrs. Mary Walker E. Fletcher has been selected to be a finalist in the 12th Annual Miss Virginia National Teen-ager Pag eant to be held at the Lake Wright Quality Inn, Virginia Beach, on April 8, 9, and 10, 1988. Outstanding young ladies from all over the state will compete for the title, 750 CASH. 8,000 in scholarships, and many other prizes.  Miss Fletcher is sponsored by The Allied Community Pharmacy of Rust burg, Roger Akers, pharmac ist, The Farmers National Bank of Appomattox, The Rustburg Mini- Mart and her father, Mr. Neal Fletcher. Miss National Teen-ager Pag eants award more than 1,000,000 in cash and tuition scholarships and prizes annually all across the nation. Judging is based on scholastic achievement-leadership, poise-per sonality, and appearance. Contest ants may compete either in talent or essay competition. There is no swimsuit competition. Miss Virginia National Teen-ager will compete in the Miss National Teen-ager Pageant in August to be televised. A state winner from all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands will be represented at the National Pageant. Each contestant will participate in the Volunteer Community Service Program of the National Teen-ager Pageant.

document.text: The Annual Meeting of Shareholders of The Farmers National Bank, Appomattox, Virginia, was held at the Banking House on Tuesday, February 20,1973, at 230 p.m. The Articles of Association of the Bank provides that the number of Directors elected at the Shareholders Meeting be determined by vote of the Shareholders. A resolution was passed at the meeting esta blishing the number of Dir ectors at 14. The persons named below, all of whom were members of the Board of Directors, were elected to serve for another term which ends at the 1974 Annual Meeting of the Share holders. Elected were W. M. Abbitt, Attorney-at-Law and Member of the U. S. House of Repre sentatives, retired Eugene W. Carson, Dairy Farmer and District Extension Agent Em eritus John C. document.text: Luther J. Morris Lu.f. Jr Jackson Morris, a form er, meinber of the Appomattox Town Council and former chair man of the Appomattox County Welfare Board, died Sunday morning in Lynchburg General Hospital after an illness of sev eral months. He was 83. Born in Appomattox County, he was a son of Nathaniel and Mary Elizabeth Ferguson Mor ris. His wife was the late Mrs. Alice J. Proffitt Morris. He was a retired mail carrier, a vice president of Farmers National Bank in Appomattox and a form er member of the Masonic Lodge. He was a member of Liberty Baptist Church and a former deacon of the church. Surviving are a son, Garland J. Morris, of Newport News a brother, Wiley M. Morris, of Ap pomattox a sister, Mrs. J. Les lie Gordon, and three grandchil dren. Funeral services were held Tuesday at 2 p.m. ir. Liberty Baptist Church with Rev. O. D. Moore and Rev. J. Marshall Walker officiating. Burial was in the Liberty Cemetery. Pallbearers were W. D. Mor ris, Leslie Gordon, Jr., Howard Gilbert, Hunter Paris, Hunter Dickerson, Nathaniel Ferguson, and Robert Lucado.

document.text: The total assets of the two banka at Appomattox have crossed the iii..lion dollar mark, according to financial statements published today. The Bank of Appomattox and the Farmers National Bank in their Ap ril statements sho,w total assets of 1,081,785.99 and combined deposits of 929,824.64. These figures represent nice in-  creases over the combined total of the first of the current year, and indicate that Appomattox is sharing in the general wave of prosperity now sweeping over the Old Domin ion, attributed in part to the vaijt federal defense program spending. No defense industries are located in Appomattox, but many men from here are employed in defense pro jects in various parts of the state. Itn fact, there H a definite shortage of skilled labor here at the present time. Appomattox is the banking head quarters for a large area in central Virginia, and the local institutions enjoy the confidence and patronage of the public for many surrounding counties as well as Appomattox. The two statements will be found bn Page Eight.

document.text: Now that the epidemic of bank closings in Virginia has been halted, we may take this opportunity to congratulate the officials of two of the finest banks in Virginia, the Bank of Appomattox and the Farmers National Bank, for their splen did condition. When dozens of Virginia banks closed and others trembled, these two banks remained firm and strong. They are more strong ly .emplanted in the hearts of their friends now than ever. Its a wonderful tribute to the men who have guided them through Admittedly perilous times.

document.text: F in a n c ia l In stitu tio n s For a long time there were no financial institutions in th County. In the early seventies, The Farmers  Merchants Saving Bank was organized at Pamplin, with J. R. Franklin as president, and W. D. Thornton as cashier, which served the people of that section until, the early nineties, and then closed of its own accord. In 1901 The Bank of Appomattox was or ganized, with a capital of 10,000, with R. F. Burke as cashier,, who served as cashier and president until his death in 1924, when he was succeeded by his son, R. L. Burke. In December, 1905, the State Bank of Pamplin was organized with a mini mum capital of 5,000.00 and operated until September, 1931, serving the people of that scetion of the County. In Septem ber, 1918, The Farmers National Bank was organized and opened for business, with a minimum capital of 50,000, with A. R. Harwood as cashier, who is still serving in that capacity. The Bank of Appomattox and The Farmers National Bank have operated since their organization, and now have combined as sets of 2,277,808.51, and have been great factors in the busi ness and agricultural development of the County.
